questions.text: Most common childhood epilepsy syndrome is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rolandic epilepsy 

Explanation:

Most common seizure seen in children is febrile seizures and leading childhood epilepsy syndrome is Beningn rolandic epilepsy( bening because of self limiting nature). Note that question is not asking most type of seizures in children but the most common type of epilepsy syndrome. 

Benign Rolandic Epilepsy

  • Occurs in children aged 4–10 years

  • Seizures often occur during sleep and involve face and cause drooling of saliva. Episodes during awake stage might lead to speech arrest 

  • Self-limiting, resolves by adolescence

  • EEG: centrotemporal spikes

  • Carbamazepine is used for focal seizures seen

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with a history of seizures and poor medication adherence presents to the ER after a 6-minute seizure followed by another, with impaired consciousness between episodes. She is unresponsive and has labored breathing. Which of the following is correct about managment this patient?

choices.text: iv Lorazepam followed by phenytoin infusion
Rectal diazepam followed by midazolam drip

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) iv Lorazepam followed by Phenytoin infusion

Explanation

The scenario describes a seizure lasting 6 minutes with impaired consciousness during the interictal period, indicating impending and early status epilepticus. The treatment in this case is iv Lorazepam followed by Phenytoin infusion. 

B: Rectal diazepam + midazolam drip: Rectal route is for prehospital or pediatric use; midazolam infusion is for refractory SE.

C: Intranasal midazolam: Used if IV access is unavailable, not in ER setting with IV access and labored breathing.

D: IV midazolam infusion: Reserved for refractory status (seizures not controlled with first/second-line therapy).

GCSE refers to either:

  1. A single generalized convulsive seizure lasting ≥ 5 minutes
    (i.e., tonic-clonic activity that doesn’t stop)
    OR

  2. Two or more discrete generalized seizures with:

    • Impaired consciousness between them (i.e., no return to baseline interictal mental status)

    • Usually within 30 minutes of each other

Impending and early SE is timeline of 5-30 minutes.

Established and early SE is 30 minutes to 48 hours.

Late refractory SE is > 48 hours.

questions.text: 4 year girl presents to the clinic with a frequent seizure episodes. You notice she has port-wine stain on her forehead and upper eyelid. Neuroimaging reveals tram-track calcifications in the brain. Which type of seizures is seen in this condition ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Focal seizures 

Explanation:

The combination of a port-wine stain in the trigeminal distribution, seizures, unilateral weakness, and tram-track calcifications aligns with the clinical features of Sturge-Weber syndrome.It has focal-onset seizures because of leptomeningeal angiomas causing unilateral cortical irritation. They can secondarily generalize to tonic-clonic seizures.Seizures usually start in infancy, often within the first year of life.

Mnemonic: STURGE

  • S: Seizures – Caused by cavernous angiomas in the brain, often leading to epilepsy.
  • T: Tram-track gyriform calcifications – Visible calcifications on brain imaging, seen in areas of abnormal blood vessel growth.
  • U: Unilateral weakness – Hemiparesis (weakness on one side of the body) opposite the facial port-wine stain.
  • R: Reduced intellect – Intellectual disability is frequently observed.
  • G: Glaucoma – Increased intraocular pressure, which may cause buphthalmos (enlargement of the eye).
  • E: Epilepsy – Seizures are common due to underlying brain malformations.

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is earliest to be seen in this neurocutaneous disorder
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ash leaf macules 

Explanation:

The presence of A= facial angiofibromas, B= shagreen patches, C= Hypomelanotic macules aligns perfectly with the clinical features of tuberous sclerosis. Hypopigmented macules (also called “ash leaf spots”) are usually the earliest skin manifestation, often seen at birth or in infancy.  Adenoma sebaceum appear between 2–5 years of age and become more prominent at puberty, due to hormonal influences.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about SSPE?

choices.text: Delayed neurological complication of measles vaccine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Delayed neurological complication of measles vaccine

Explanation:

SSPE is caused by persistent defective measles virus in the brain (usually wild-type virus). It appears an average  of ~6–8 years after natural measles infection. It is not caused by MMR vaccine (measles-mumps-rubella). The risk is highest if measles infection occurred before age 2 of years. Inosine pranobex (Inoprinosine) is an antiviral and immunomodulatory agent that has been used to improve survival along with intraventricular interferon. 

SSPE can be diagnosed if three out of five criteria are met:

  1. Typical clinical presentation (progressive neurologic deterioration)
  2. EEG showing stereotyped periodic complexes/ Periodic generalized high-voltage slow-wave complexes
  3. Brain biopsy or autopsy with characteristic histopathological findings
  4. CSF globulin levels greater than 20% of total CSF protein
  5. Elevated CSF measles antibody titers (≥1/4 by hemagglutination inhibition or ≥1/20 by ELISA)

questions.text: A 10 year boy unvaccinated child is  brought to hospital with increased irritability, social withdrawal, and difficulty in school. On examination he has myoclonic jerks and motor difficulties. EEG shows periodic spikes of slow-wave discharges occurring every 4–10 seconds. Select the best investigation to be performed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C:  CSF shows Anti measles antibody

Periodic spikes in EEG with myoclonic jerks in an unvaccinated child makes you think in terms of SSPE that usually present at this age group. CSF IgG antibody will help in confirmation of diagnosis. 

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)

About
  • SSPE is a rare, severe complication of the measles virus.
  • It typically presents in early adolescence and has a progressive course with high mortality.
  • Vaccination has reduced measles cases, but SSPE remains a concern due to measles re-emergence.

Pathophysiology
  • Caused by the measles virus, which is highly contagious and transmitted via aerosols.
  • The latency period ranges from 6-8 years post-infection, with shorter periods in younger children.
  • The virus targets lymphocytes and epithelial cells, causing significant immunosuppression.
  • SSPE is associated with a poor cellular immune response and persistent viral presence in the CNS.
  • Neuronal entry and infection mechanisms are not fully understood; mutations in the virus may facilitate evasion of the immune response.

Clinical Features
  • Symptoms typically arise 6-8 years after measles infection, starting with cognitive decline.
  • Early signs include personality changes, poor school performance, and lethargy.
  • Stage I: Personality and behavioural changes, including irritability, dementia, lethargy, social withdrawal, and speech regression.
  • Stage II: Progressive decline in motor function characterized by myoclonus, dyskinesia, and dystonia.
  • Stage III: Development of extrapyramidal symptoms, posturing, and spasticity.
  • Stage IV: Akinetic mutism, autonomic failure, or transition to a vegetative state.
  • Progressive motor function decline occurs, with myoclonus and focal paralysis.
  • Patients may develop seizures, leading to vegetative states or akinetic mutism.
  • Visual symptoms may precede other signs, including retinal lesions and vision loss.
  • Atypical presentations can involve psychiatric symptoms and rapid decline, especially in younger patients.

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with their respective EEGs.


	
		
			
			1) Focal seizure
			
			
			a) 
			
		
		
			
			2) Absence seizure
			
			
			b) 
			
		
		
			
			3) Hypsarrythmia
			
			
			c) 
			
		
		
			
			4) Periodic sharp wave complexes
			
			
			d)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

Explanation:

Focal seizure

-EEG shows localized spikes or sharp waves in the region of the brain corresponding to the seizure onset.

Absence seizure

-EEG exhibits 3 Hz spike-and-slow wave discharges, typically generalized and symmetric.

Hypsarrythmia

-EEG presents chaotic, bursts of bilateral asynchronous high-amplitude slow waves interspersed with spikes followed by generalized voltage attenuation.

Periodic sharp wave complexes

-EEG reveals generalized synchronized high-voltage sharp waves occurring at 1–2 Hz.

questions.text: A 62 y/o man presents with rapid cognitive decline, visual disturbances, and myoclonus. An EEG shows localized frontal intermittent rhythmical delta activity (FIRDA) that evolves to periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWC) after a few weeks. Based on this presentation and EEG findings, which of the following conditions is most likely associated with his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

Explanation:

The progression from localized frontal intermittent rhythmical delta activity (FIRDA) to PSWC is characteristic of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), along with the patient's rapid cognitive decline and myoclonus.

Periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWC)

  • The first EEG finding in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is often localized frontal intermittent rhythmical delta activity (FIRDA).
  • FIRDA evolves to typical periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWC) after a few weeks.
  • PSWC is characterized by generalized synchronized high-voltage sharp waves with frequencies of 1–2 Hz.
  • While PSWC usually appear generalized, they may exhibit lateralized or localized distributions in the early stages of CJD.
  • PSWC is one of the criteria for the clinical diagnosis of CJD.
  • Hence, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) presents with PSWC and myoclonic jerks.

 

Periodic sharp wave complexes are seen on EEG

Triphasic waves

  • Triphasic waves are abnormal EEG waveforms characterized by high-amplitude sharp waves with three distinctive phases.
  • They are seen in association with multiple clinical conditions, including encephalopathy, structural brain lesions etc.
  • Duration: 300 to 600 milliseconds.
  • Phases: First phase (negative), second phase (positive, amplitude >70 microvolts), third phase (slow negative).
  • Frequency: Periodic, at a rate of 0.5 Hz to 2 Hz.
  • Distribution: Diffuse with synchronous bifrontal and central predominance, showing fronto-occipital time lag.
  • Causes:
    • Encephalopathy: Hepatic, Renal and Metabolic (e.g., hypernatremia, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia)
    • Structural Abnormalities:
      • Cerebral abscess
      • Thalamic gliomas
      • Pontine stroke
      • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)
      • Alzheimer's disease
    • Other Conditions:
      • Ictal or postictal states
      • Serotonin syndrome
      • Lithium toxicity
      • Antibiotic toxicity (e.g., cefepime)

 

Hepatic and renal encephalopathy (Options A & C) may cause altered mental status, but not the rapid cognitive decline, myoclonus, and specific EEG findings seen in CJD.

 

Alzheimer’s disease (Option D) typically has a much slower progression and lacks these EEG patterns and associated myoclonus.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate born at 39 weeks gestation by venthouse is having jitteriness. Which of the following is correct about this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subtle seizure

Explanation:

  • Subtle seizures are the most common seizure type in newborns, often presenting with changes in tone or subtle movements called jitteriness that often go unnoticed.
  • Types of Movements:
    • Ocular Movements: Includes random eye movements, sustained conjugate tonic deviation, eyelid blinking or fluttering, eye-rolling, and nystagmus.
    • Oral-Buccal-Lingual Movements: Such as sucking, smacking, chewing, and tongue protrusions.
    • Progressive Movements: Including rowing, swimming, pedalling, thrashing, or struggling movements.
    • Complex Purposeless Movements: Characterized by sudden arousal, episodic limb hyperactivity, and crying.

Benign rolandic epilepsy (Option A) is the most common type of epilepsy in children. It's also known as benign epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes (BECTS).

  • Symptoms- Twitching, numbness, or tingling in the face or tongue, which can cause garbled speech.
  • Occur most often at night, or when falling asleep or waking up.
  • It usually lasts up to two minutes.
  • Seizures typically stop by the time a child is 19 years old.
  • Some children with BRE have problems with learning, speech, or behavioural issues.
  • In most cases, children with BRE don't need medication because the seizures aren't a big problem. Most children stop having seizures within 2 to 4 years after they begin.

Febrile seizures (Option C) are the most common type of epilepsy in infants and young children aged 6 months to 5 years, with a peak incidence between 12 and 18 months.

  • They are associated with febrile illnesses but have no identifiable cause, such as CNS infection or metabolic issues.
  • Simple FS: Lasts less than 15 minutes, typically associated with common infections. High risk of developing temporal lobe epilepsy.
  • Complex FS: Involves multiple seizures during a single febrile illness, lasting 15-30 minutes.
  • Febrile Status Epilepticus (FSE): Seizures lasting over 30 minutes, accounting for 25-52% of status epilepticus cases in children.
  • A higher risk of FSE is noted in children with underlying neurological disorders.


Myoclonic seizures (Option D) are less common than subtle seizures. They are rapid, single, or rhythmic repetitive jerks that involve a finger, limb, or the entire body. They are more common in pre-term infants than term infants. It may resemble the Moro reflex and startling responses. It is associated with severe brain damage.

questions.text: A 25 y/o woman with a history of catamenial epilepsy reports an increase in seizure frequency just before her menstrual period. She is currently taking carbamazepine and is newly started on OCPs by her GP for contraception. What is the most appropriate advice for her regarding her current situation?

choices.text: Change to Levetiracetam due to high risk of neural tube defects
Switch to Valproate to reduce risk of neural tube defects
Consider alternative contraception methods due to carbamazepine's effect on oral contraceptives.
Stop all antiseizure medications while trying to conceive.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Consider alternative contraception methods due to carbamazepine's effect on oral contraceptives.

Explanation:

Carbamazepine can significantly reduce the effectiveness of oral contraceptives, so alternative methods (like IUDs) are recommended for women not planning to conceive.

Catamenial Epilepsy
  • Increased seizure frequency around menses due to estrogen/progesterone effects or antiseizure drug level changes.
  • Some women may require increased antiseizure drug dosages during menses.
  • Natural progestins or intramuscular medroxyprogesterone may benefit certain women.

Pregnancy
  • ~50% of women experience unchanged seizure frequency; ~30% may increase, and ~20% decrease.
  • Monitoring of serum antiseizure drug levels is essential during pregnancy.
  • Lamotrigine and levetiracetam are recommended as first-line monotherapy for generalized and focal onset seizures.
  • The higher teratogenic risk with multiple antiseizure drugs is noted.
  • Valproic acid is strongly associated with adverse fetal outcomes and is thus contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • Folate supplementation (1–4 mg/d) is recommended due to antifolate effects of anticonvulsants.
  • Enzyme-inducing drugs (phenytoin, carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, topiramate, phenobarbital, primidone) may cause vitamin K deficiency in newborns. Hence mothers should take oral vitamin K, and infants should receive intramuscular vitamin K at birth.

Contraception
  • Certain antiseizure medications (carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, topiramate) reduce oral contraceptive efficacy via enzyme induction.
  • Alternative contraception methods (IUDs, long-acting reversible contraceptives) should be considered.

Breast-Feeding
  • Antiseizure medications are excreted in breast milk at varying levels (5% for valproic acid to 300% for levetiracetam).
  • Encouraged to breastfeed unless infant shows signs of drug effects (e.g., lethargy, poor feeding).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can worsen GTCS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lamotrigine 

Explanation:

Carbamazepine blocks voltage gated sodium channels and suppresses focal seizures but in GTCS it can disrupt normal inhibitory feedback and can exacerbate generalized seizure activity. Hence, it is contraindicated in idiopathic generalized epilepsies.

Drugs used in GTCS are Valproate, lamotrigine, Levetiracetam, topiramate.

questions.text: Which statement about Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy Syndrome is FALSE?

choices.text: EEG may show unilateral or bilateral anterior temporal spikes.
MRI typically reveals an enlarged hippocampus with trilaminar architecture.
It is often refractory to anticonvulsants but may respond well to surgical intervention.
Auras, postictal disorientation and memory loss can occur.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) MRI typically reveals an enlarged hippocampus with trilaminar architecture.

Explanation:

MRI findings in Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy usually show a smaller hippocampus with a loss of the normal trilaminar architecture, reflecting the structural changes associated with the syndrome.

Mesial Temporal lobe Epilepsy Syndrome

History
  • Often associated with a history of febrile seizures
  • Rarely involves generalised seizures
  • A family history of epilepsy may be present
  • Seizures can remit but may reoccur
  • Typically has an early onset

Clinical Observations(Option D ruled out)
  • Auras are commonly experienced.
  • Postictal disorientation.
  • Behavioural arrest or staring episodes.
  • Memory loss can occur.
  • Presence of complex automatisms.
  • Dysphasia may occur if the focus is in the dominant hemisphere.
  • Unilateral posturing is observed.

Laboratory Studies
  • EEG may show unilateral or bilateral anterior temporal spikes. (Option A ruled out)
  • Interictal PET scans reveal hypometabolism.
  • Ictal SPECT scans demonstrate hyperperfusion.
  • Intracranial amobarbital (Wada) test may indicate material-specific memory deficits.

MRI Findings
  • The hippocampus appears smaller with increased signal on T2-weighted sequences.
  • Loss of the trilaminar architecture of the hippocampus. (Option B)
  • Reduced size of the temporal lobe
  • Enlargement of the temporal horn.

Pathologic Findings
  • Characterized by a selective loss of specific cell populations within the hippocampus in most cases
  • Dispersion of the granule cell layer and gliosis are noted.

Treatment
  • Refractory to anticonvulsants.
  • Responds well to Surgical intervention. (Option C ruled out) ​​​

questions.text: A 7 y/o girl presents to the pediatric neurology clinic with a history of multiple seizure types. Her parents report that she has experienced GTCS, atonic seizures where she suddenly drops to the ground, and atypical absence seizures. The child has also shown signs of cognitive impairment. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding her condition?

choices.text: Characterized by bilateral myoclonic jerks that are most frequent in the morning.
The EEG findings show diffuse, symmetric, bilateral 4 to 6 Hz polyspike and wave discharges.
Valproate and Topiramate are used in treatment.
The condition typically presents in early adolescence.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Valproate and Topiramate are used in treatment.

Explanation:

The diagnosis is likely Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome, characterized by multiple seizure types, including generalized tonic-clonic, atonic, and atypical absence seizures, along with cognitive impairment in a child. The presence of these varied seizures and cognitive issues supports this diagnosis.

  • Valproate and Topiramate are among the first-line treatment options for Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome.

Characteristics

Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome

Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME/ JANZ Syndrome)

Onset

Occurs in children

Early adolescence (Option D ruled out)

Cause

Associated with various CNS dysfunction causes (e.g., de novo mutations, developmental abnormalities, perinatal hypoxia)

Unknown cause; polygenic factors suggested

Seizure Types

Multiple seizure types, including generalized tonic-clonic, atonic, and atypical absence seizures

Primarily bilateral myoclonic jerks; may also have generalized tonic-clonic and absence seizures

Myoclonic Seizures

Not a primary feature

Most frequent in the morning after awakening; can be provoked by sleep deprivation. (Option A ruled out)

Consciousness

Impaired cognitive function in most cases

Preserved unless myoclonus is severe

EEG Findings

Shows slow (<3 Hz) spike-and-wave discharges.

Shows diffuse, symmetric, bilateral 4 to 6 Hz polyspike and wave discharges, predominantly in the fronto-central region. (Option B ruled out)

Ictal EEG recordings reveal 10-16 Hz polyspike discharges that correlate with myoclonic jerks.

Treatment

Valproate, lamotrigine, and topiramate

Valproic acid

questions.text: A 25 y/o man is brought to the ED after experiencing a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. An EEG is performed after the seizure. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the EEG findings associated with his seizure?

choices.text: The interictal EEG shows electrodecremental response
During the tonic phase, the EEG typically shows a progressive increase in generalized low-voltage fast activity.
The postictal EEG usually reveals localized spikes corresponding to the seizure focus.
The EEG during the clonic phase shows low frequency polyspikes with variable amplitude

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) During the tonic phase, the EEG typically shows a progressive increase in generalized low-voltage fast activity.

Explanation:

In the case of GTCS, EEG during the tonic phase shows a progressive increase in generalized low-voltage fast activity. and clonic phase there is High-amplitude spike-wave bursts.

Hack to Rememeber

In the clonic phase patient is shaking violenty, so high amplitude and S for Spike wave bursts. 

Focal Seizure- EEG

GTCS- EEG
  • The routine interictal EEG in patients with focal seizures is often normal. (Option A ruled out)
  • It may show brief discharges, such as epileptiform spikes or sharp waves.
  • Focal seizures can arise from areas like the medial temporal lobe or inferior frontal lobe, which may be distant from the scalp.
  • As a result, the EEG recorded during the seizure may be nonlocalizing.
  • The region of seizure onset can be identified using surgically placed intracranial electrodes.
  • During the tonic phase, the EEG shows a progressive increase in generalized low-voltage fast activity. (Option B)
  • This is followed by generalized high-amplitude polyspike discharges.
  • In the clonic phase, high-amplitude activity is typically interrupted by slow waves, creating a spike-and-slow-wave pattern. (Option D ruled out)
  • Generalized seizures tend to terminate synchronously across widespread brain regions.
  • The postictal EEG displays diffuse suppression of all cerebral activity, followed by slowing that gradually recovers as the patient awakens. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with a recently diagnosed PNET experiences recurrent episodes of fainting, often preceded by sweating, tremors and confusion. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Metabolic cause 

Explanation:

PNET implies pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. This implies he can be having insulinoma that would be causing hypoglycemia ( metabolic cause).  Dyselectrolytemia is second close option that can be explained if PNET is a VIPoma. The answer is based on the fact that insulinoma is more common. RBS of this patient along with RIA Fasting insulin and serum electrolytes will help in that exclusion or inclusion. 

Extra mile 

Vasovagal Syncope vs. Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures (GTCS):

Features

Vasovagal Syncope (Neurally Mediated Syncope)

Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures (GTCS)

Cause

It results from a reflex that alters autonomic outflow, leading to bradycardia, vasodilation, and reduced cardiac output. This lowers systemic blood pressure and causes cerebral hypoperfusion, leading to syncope.

GTCS are caused by widespread abnormal electrical activity in the brain, leading to both tonic (stiffening) and clonic (jerking) muscle contractions.

Triggers

Emotional stress, pain, standing upright for long periods, warm environments, dehydration, blood loss, and sight of blood.

GTCS can occur without clear triggers.

Pathophysiology

Increased parasympathetic outflow (vagal activation) and inhibition of sympathetic outflow result in bradycardia and hypotension. Cerebral blood flow falls below compensatory limits, causing loss of consciousness.

Seizures begin abruptly, often without warning. The tonic phase involves sustained muscle contraction, leading to symptoms like the "ictal cry" due to vocal cord contraction. The clonic phase features rhythmic jerking as muscles relax intermittently.

Symptoms
  • Premonitory: Dizziness, lightheadedness, nausea, yawning, sweating, pallor, and palpitations.
  • During the event: Transient loss of consciousness, uprolling of the eyes, dilated pupils, possible muscle jerks (myoclonus), and rarely, urinary or faecal incontinence.
  • EEG pattern: "Slow-flat-slow" pattern with high-amplitude slow waves, followed by EEG flattening.
  • Premonitory: Some patients have vague premonitory symptoms, but stereotypical auras are rare.
  • During the event: Tonic contraction followed by clonic jerking. The patient may experience cyanosis, tongue biting, loss of bladder/bowel control, and increased heart rate and blood pressure.
  • Postictal: Period of confusion lasting minutes to hours, fatigue, headache, muscle soreness, and incontinence. Postictal confusion is a prominent feature.
  • EEG pattern: Low-voltage fast activity during the tonic phase, followed by a spike-and-slow-wave pattern during the clonic phase. Postictal suppression of brain activity is observed.

Recovery

Quick recovery of consciousness without prolonged confusion. Postictal confusion and hallucinations are rare.

GTCS has a prolonged postictal phase with confusion and fatigue.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with brief episodes of sudden flexion of the trunk and limbs, lasting a few seconds. EEG shows hypsarrhythmia, and during the episodes, there's marked background suppression on the EEG. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Epileptic spasms

Explanation: 


The clinical description of brief, sustained flexion, age group (infants), and EEG showing hypsarrhythmia with background suppression are classic for epileptic spasms. They  are characterized by brief, sustained flexion or extension of mainly proximal muscles, including the trunk and are also known as salaam convulsions. Key word of MCQ is hypsarrhythmia which is marked by diffuse giant slow waves with a chaotic background of irregular, multifocal spikes and sharp waves.

Option D Lennox gastaut syndrome has GTCS, Atonic and atypical absence siezures with EEG of < 3 Hz.  Absence seizures are characterized by brief lapses in consciousness/ vacant staring spells without the tonic or flexor posturing and 3/sec spike and slow wave pattern.

questions.text: A 23 year patient presents with sudden, brief muscle jerks on loud auditory stimuli and dementia. T2/FLAIR MRI shows hyperintensity in the pulvinar nucleus of the thalamus. What is the first differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease 

Explanation:

The diagnosis is most likely to be variant creutzfeldt-jakob disease , due to the combination of dementia and myoclonic jerks( startle myoclonus ) . Hyperintensity in the pulvinar nucleus of the thalamus on T2/FLAIR MRI is considered highly specific for vCJD. It is also called the "hockey stick sign" when it extends to the dorsomedial thalamus. 

 

Myoclonic Seizures :

  • Definition: Sudden, brief muscle contractions that can involve a part of or the entire body.
  • Physiological Example: Normal myoclonus occurs as a sudden jerk when falling asleep.
  • Pathological Causes: Most commonly seen in metabolic disorders, degenerative CNS diseases, or anoxic brain injury.
    • VCJD -Variant Creutzfeldt Jakob Disease: Patient has a history of consumption of poor-quality meat It may contain Prion particles, which, on entering the body, multiply in the cytoplasm of neurons. It irritates neurons, leading to their abnormal firing.
  • Aetiology: Myoclonic seizures are epileptic events caused by cortical dysfunction, as opposed to subcortical or spinal causes.
  • EEG Findings: Shows bilaterally synchronous spike-and-slow-wave discharges just before the myoclonic jerk, with muscle artefact.
  • Association with Other Seizures: Myoclonic seizures often occur alongside other generalized seizures. They are the hallmark feature of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME).

 

Epileptic spasms (Option A) typically occur in infants and present with different EEG findings (hypsarrhythmia) rather than spike-and-slow-wave discharges.

 

Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (Option B): Although JME can cause myoclonic seizures and spike-and-slow-wave discharges, the history of beef consumption strongly suggests prion disease.

 

Anoxic brain injury (Option D): There's no evidence of hypoxia or brain injury, and the patient’s symptoms are better explained by prion-related vCJD.

questions.text: 7 year  child is brought to the clinic due to frequent episodes of "daydreaming" during school, which last for a few seconds and are accompanied by subtle eyelid blinking. Which of the following is correct about this condition?

choices.text: Episodes can be stopped by hyperventilation
Episodes are triggered by photic stimulation
< 2.5 Hz spike and slow wave pattern
Occur due to defect of sodium channel closure in thalamocortical circuit

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Episodes are triggered by photic stimulation

Explanation:

This is a case of Absence seizures. They occur due to T-type calcium channel dysfunction in the thalamus, which causes rhythmic 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges on EEG. They are often triggered by hyperventilation, stress, or flashing lights in mainly children aged 4–14 years.

questions.text: A 35 y/o woman experiences sudden unresponsiveness during conversations, followed by repetitive hand movements and lip-smacking. Afterwards, she seems confused and does not remember the event. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Focal Seizure with Impaired Awareness

Explanation:
The patient's unresponsiveness, automatisms, and post-seizure confusion are characteristics of focal seizure with impaired awareness.

 

Focal Seizure with Impaired Awareness

  • Impaired Awareness: During the seizure, patients lose their ability to respond to external stimuli and are unaware of the event. They may not recall the seizure (ictal phase) afterwards.
  • Aura: Seizures often begin with an aura, where patients experience unusual internal sensations such as fear, déjà vu, depersonalisation, or visual distortions like micropsia (objects appearing smaller) or macropsia (objects appearing larger). These are subjective events not observable by others.
  • Motionless Stare: The ictal phase is typically marked by a sudden, motionless stare, signalling the onset of impaired awareness.
  • Automatisms: Patients may perform automatic, involuntary behaviours like chewing, lip-smacking, swallowing, or repetitive hand movements. More complex actions, like displaying emotions or running, may also occur.
  • Post-Seizure Confusion: After the seizure, patients are often confused, and the recovery time can range from seconds to over an hour.

Postictal Symptoms: Neurological deficits such as anterograde amnesia, aphasia, or visual disturbances may follow the seizure, depending on which cortical regions were involved.

Image showing abnormal high voltage in right temporal leads. Since the abnormal electrical activity is seen only in some leads, it is a focal seizure.

 

Absence Seizure (Option A): Typically involves brief episodes of staring without postictal confusion or automatisms, which is more common in children.

 

Panic Attack (Option B): Presents with intense fear and physical symptoms, but does not include automatisms or loss of awareness.

 

Focal Seizure with Intact Awareness (Option D): Involves preserved awareness throughout the event, which is not seen in this case.

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman experiences involuntary movements that begin in her right hand and progressively spread to her right arm and face. She remains fully aware throughout the episode. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Jacksonian march

Explanation:

The patient has focal involvement without impairment of awareness. Jacksonian March describes a focal motor seizure where abnormal movements start in one part of the body, like the hand, and gradually spread to other nearby areas, such as the arm and face. The seizure progresses in a “marching” pattern, following the motor cortex's representation of the body.

 

Absence seizure (Option A): This seizure typically involves a brief loss of awareness, where the person appears to “zone out” and is unresponsive. It is predominantly seen in children. Motor symptoms are usually absent, and the person does not experience the spreading involuntary movements seen in this patient.

 

Todd’s paralysis (Option B): Todd’s paralysis is a temporary weakness (paresis) affecting the same area involved in a seizure. It usually occurs after the seizure has ended (postictally), which is not the case in this patient. It is also a feature of focal motor seizures with intact awareness.

 

Epilepsia partialis continua (Option C): This refers to prolonged, continuous focal motor seizures, often restricted to one part of the body, lasting hours or even days. While awareness is usually intact, the condition is characterised by ongoing motor activity rather than the brief spreading movements described here.

questions.text: 20-year-old  student experiences episodes of sudden drop attacks with brief loss of consciousness and confusion after the episode. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Atonic seizure

Explanation:

Post-ictal confusion further supports a seizure origin rather than a cardiovascular syncope. Orthostatic hypotension usually occurs upon standing, is gradual in onset, and typically does not cause post-event confusion.
In contrast, atonic seizures present with sudden loss of muscle tone, leading to abrupt falls (drop attacks) and brief loss of consciousness. It is not GTCS, as there is no tonic-clonic movement or prolonged post-ictal phase—only a sudden loss of tone. It is not myoclonic seizure, because those involve brief jerks without loss of consciousness or post-ictal confusion.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to OPD with complaints of repeated episodes of blank staring, and lip-smacking movements lasting around 1–2 minutes. He is confused afterward and has no memory of the episode. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Focal seizure 

Explanation:

This is a focal seizure with impaired awareness, as indicated by the automatisms (lip-smacking), duration of 1–2 minutes, and post-ictal confusion with amnesia. In contrast, absence seizures are brief (typically <20 seconds), occur mostly in young  children, and lack post-ictal confusion or automatisms. The presence of prolonged altered awareness and automatisms strongly points to temporal lobe epilepsy.

questions.text: A 19-year-old medical student collapses in the anatomy dissection hall. His friends report a brief period of limb jerking lasting about 10–15 seconds during the episode. He regained consciousness in a minute, he appeared pale around the lips with sweating on forehead. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Vasovagal syncope 

 

Explanation:

Vasovagal syncope can sometimes include brief convulsive movements, especially if there's cerebral hypoperfusion. The event could have been triggered by prolonged standing. GTCS presents with post-ictal confusion , delayed recovery, incontinence, and often tongue b

  • Features against GTCS:

    1. Autonomic features like sweating 

    2. No tongue biting or incontinence

    3. Perioral pallor ( GTCS epidose has perioral pallor) 

    4. Quick recovery within 1 minute
